zmanim.description: 72 minutes after sunset throughout the year, provided sun is at least 8° below horizon.
zmanim.formula_dsl: if ((solar(8, after_sunset) - sunset) > 72min) { solar(8, after_sunset) } else { sunset + 72min }

zmanim.description: Stringency from Dawn 1 (16.1°) to nightfall at 16.1°, so beginning and end of day are equal.
zmanim.publisher_comment: As printed in many calendars, calculating from Alos HaShachar at 16.1° until Tzeis HaKochavim at 16.1°, so that the beginning and end of the day are symmetrical. This time is used as a stringency for the Torah obligation of Krias Shema.

zmanim.description: Plag HaMincha according to MA/Terumas Hadeshen practiced in many communities. One and a quarter proportional hours before nightfall, calculating 72 minutes before sunrise to 72 minutes after sunset.
zmanim.publisher_comment: We have printed the Plag according to the Magen Avraham / Terumas HaDeshen, as practised in many communities. This is one and a quarter hours before Tzeis HaKochavim (72 minutes after sunset). Since this pertains to the time for accepting Shabbos, we have printed it only for our community.

zmanim.description: Dawn calculated as 1/8 of the day before sunrise (Minchas Yitzchak stringency)
zmanim.publisher_comment: According to the calculation of one-eighth of the day, as printed by the Minchas Yitzchok as a stringency.

zmanim.description: Latest time for morning prayer using MGA with fixed 72 minute day extension
zmanim.publisher_comment:
This is one third of the halachic day, calculated from Alos HaShachar (Method B) until Tzeis HaKochavim.

For those who calculate Alos HaShachar as 72 minutes before sunrise, Sof Zman Tefillah according to the Magen Avraham is always 24 minutes before Sof Zman Tefillah according to the Gra.

zmanim.description: Time when three small consecutive stars are visible. Sun 7.08° below horizon.
zmanim.publisher_comment: The time for lighting candles and for the appearance of small stars. This is when the sun is 7.08 degrees below the horizon. Regarding Rabbinic fasts, there may be room for leniency of a few minutes—consult a competent halachic authority.

zmanim.description: Earliest tallis/tefillin time for pressing circumstances (2° earlier than standard)
End time for eating in the morning on a minor fast day. One who sleeps and then wakes must stop eating at this time.
zmanim.publisher_comment: Per Orach Chaim 564. Uses Dawn 2 (12°) as the cutoff.

zmanim.description: Dawn calculated as 1/8th of the day before sunrise, using the Manchester day definition (12° to 7.08°).
zmanim.publisher_comment: Printed by the Minchas Yitzchak as a stringency.

zmanim.description: Per Manchester Beth Din / Minchas Yitzchak using 12° dawn and 7.08° nightfall
zmanim.publisher_comment: This is one quarter of the halachic day, calculated from Alos HaShachar (Method B) until Tzeis HaKochavim as printed in the calendar.

zmanim.description: Two and a half proportional hours before sunset.
zmanim.publisher_comment: This is two and a half sha'os zmaniyos (halachic hours) before sunset.

zmanim.description: Earliest time for Maariv, lighting Shabbos candles, and Chanukah candles. One and a quarter proportional hours before sunset.
zmanim.publisher_comment: The earliest time for Maariv, for lighting Shabbos candles, and for lighting Chanukah candles. It is one and a quarter sha'os zmaniyos before sunset.

zmanim.description: The time when the sun stands at highest point between east and west. Half the time between sunrise and sunset. Midnight is 12 hours after.
zmanim.publisher_comment: This is the moment when the sun stands at its highest point in the sky, midway between east and west. It is exactly halfway between sunrise and sunset. Chatzos HaLaylah (midnight) is precisely 12 hours from Chatzos HaYom (see Igros Moshe, Orach Chaim Vol. 2, Siman 20), with a possible variation of one minute.

zmanim.description: The time when the upper edge of the sun rises above the horizon at sea level.
zmanim.publisher_comment: This is the moment when the upper edge of the sun first appears above the horizon at sea level.

zmanim.description: Latest time for Shema according to Vilna Gaon and Rabbi Zalman. One quarter of the day from sunrise to sunset.
zmanim.publisher_comment: This is one quarter of the halachic day, calculated from sunrise until sunset. This is the final time for reciting the Shema.

zmanim.description: Latest time for morning prayer according to Vilna Gaon. One third of the day from sunrise to sunset.
zmanim.publisher_comment: This is one third of the halachic day, calculated from sunrise until sunset.

zmanim.description: Time for lighting Shabbos candles and accepting Shabbos.
zmanim.publisher_comment: 15 minutes before sunset, as has been the custom from ancient times.

zmanim.description: Midnight - 12 hours after midday. Per Igros Moshe OC 2:20.
zmanim.publisher_comment: May vary by one minute from midday + 12 hours.

zmanim.description: End of fast. For rabbinic fasts, one may be lenient by several minutes.
The time when the sun is completely hidden from our eyes. Time printed is slightly before actual to be safe.
zmanim.publisher_comment: The time when the sun is completely hidden from our sight. The printed time is about one minute earlier than the true time.

zmanim.description: Earliest time for afternoon prayer. Half a proportional hour after midday, but no less than 30 minutes.
zmanim.formula_dsl: if ((proportional_hours(6.5, gra) - solar_noon) > 30min) { proportional_hours(6.5, gra) } else { solar_noon + 30min }
zmanim.publisher_comment: This is half a sha'ah zmanis (halachic hour) after Chatzos. The custom is to be stringent that it should be at least half a sha'ah zmanis and no less than 30 minutes. (In winter, when the days are short, half a sha'ah zmanis is less than 30 minutes.)

zmanim.description: End of Shabbos when three small consecutive stars are visible. Sun 8° below horizon.
zmanim.publisher_comment: When three small stars appear close together in the sky. This occurs when the sun is 8 degrees below the horizon.

zmanim.description: 72 min before sunrise to 72 min after sunset. Always 36 minutes before GRA time.
zmanim.ai_explanation: Subtracts 36 minutes from סוף זמן שמע של הגר"א to account for the difference between solar noon and clock noon due to the equation of time. The גר"א calculates זמן שמע as 3 seasonal hours from נץ, but when converting to clock time, the solar day's variation from 24 hours creates discrepancies that this adjustment corrects (שו"ע או"ח נ"ח).
zmanim.publisher_comment: This is the practice in many places, calculating from 72 minutes before sunrise to 72 minutes after sunset. According to this calculation, Sof Zman Krias Shema according to the Magen Avraham is always 36 minutes before the time of the Gra.

zmanim.description: Sun 16.1° below horizon. In polar summer (May-July), the sun does not descend to 16.1° in Manchester, so midnight (chatzos layla) is printed as dawn.
zmanim.formula_dsl: if (date >= 20-May && date <= 20-Jul) { solar_midnight } else { solar(16.1, before_sunrise) }
zmanim.publisher_comment:
This is when the sun is 16.1 degrees below the horizon. During the period when the sun does not descend this far (21st May to 21st July), we have printed the time of Alos HaShachar as midnight.

This calculation corresponds to 4 milin before sunrise—that is, the time the sun descends below the horizon in Eretz Yisroel, which is 72 minutes before sunrise during Nissan and Tishrei. This time is mentioned in the commentary of the Vilna Gaon and in the Siddur of the Alter Rebbe. It has recently become customary to print this time in community calendars in this country as a stringency, to ensure that mitzvos of the night (such as the evening Shema and Sefiras HaOmer) are completed before this time.

zmanim.description: One and a quarter proportional hours before nightfall, calculating the day from Dawn 2 (12°) until nightfall (7.08°).
zmanim.publisher_comment: This is one and a quarter sha'os zmaniyos before Tzeis HaKochavim, calculating the day from Alos HaShachar (Method B) until the printed Tzeis HaKochavim.

zmanim.description: Sun 12° below horizon. Per Minchas Yitzchak 9:9, this corresponds with reality in Northern Europe.
zmanim.publisher_comment: This is when the sun is 12 degrees below the horizon. This approach is mentioned in the responsa of the Minchas Yitzchok (Vol. 9, Siman 9), as it corresponds with observable reality. This has been the practice in many communities in Northern Europe, and this time for Alos HaShachar has been printed for nearly eighty years since the founding of the community.

zmanim.description: 72 fixed minutes before sunrise throughout the year.
zmanim.publisher_comment:
According to the calculation of 4 milin equalling a fixed 72 minutes before sunrise throughout the year. Some add a stringency in summer, accounting for a mil of 22.5 minutes, placing Alos HaShachar at 90 minutes before sunrise.

Those who follow this approach should not put on Tallis and Tefillin until some time after Alos.

zmanim.description: Earliest time for tallis and tefillin with a blessing. The printed time is 15 minutes after the actual misheyakir time.
zmanim.publisher_comment: Misheyakir is the earliest time for wearing Tallis and Tefillin and for the blessings of Krias Shema. (In cases of great need, such as setting out on a journey, one may don Tallis and Tefillin from Alos HaShachar. The Misheyakir time printed in the calendar is a quarter of an hour after the actual Misheyakir
